message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: LLM-Based Multi-Agent Systems for Software Engineering: Literature Review, Vision, and the Road Ahead
Paper Abstract: Integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into autonomous agents marks a significant shift in the research landscape by offering cognitive abilities that are competitive with human planning and reasoning. This article explores the transformative potential of integrating Large Language Models into Multi-Agent (LMA) systems for addressing complex challenges in software engineering (SE). By leveraging the collaborative and specialized abilities of multiple agents, LMA systems enable autonomous problem-solving, improve robustness, and provide scalable solutions for managing the complexity of real-world software projects. In this article, we conduct a systematic review of recent primary studies to map the current landscape of LMA applications across various stages of the software development lifecycle (SDLC). To illustrate current capabilities and limitations, we perform two case studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of state-of-the-art LMA frameworks. Additionally, we identify critical research gaps and propose a comprehensive research agenda focused on enhancing individual agent capabilities and optimizing agent synergy. Our work outlines a forward-looking vision for developing fully autonomous, scalable, and trustworthy LMA systems, laying the foundation for the evolution of Software Engineering 2.0.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Software Engineering". Here are the key findings:

## What is Software Engineering?

Software engineering is a branch of both computer science and engineering focused on designing, developing, testing, and maintaining software applications.(no content)It involves applying engineering principles and computer programming expertise to develop software systems that meet user needs.

## Historical Background

In 1968, NATO organized the first conference on software engineering, which addressed emerging challenges in software development and played a key role in formalizing guidelines and best practices for creating reliable and maintainable software.

## Key Aspects

I've completed a web search for "Large Language Models." Here's a summary of what I found:

## Definition and Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering. These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Recent Developments

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

Web search results for query: "Multi-Agent Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Multi-Agent Systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and the agents could be software agents, robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Important Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (being at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Research Areas

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment. Additionally, consensus dynamics studies how a group of agents interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange, known as the consensus problem in multi-agent systems.

Links: [{"title":"Systems development life cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_development_life_cycle"},{"title":"Software release life cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle"},{"title":"Software development process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_development_process"},{"title":"Agile software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agile_software_development"},{"title":"Web engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_engineering"},{"title":"Application lifecycle management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_lifecycle_management"},{"title":"V-model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-model"},{"title":"Collaborative development environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_development_environment"},{"title":"Process development execution system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_development_execution_system"},{"title":"Micro Focus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_Focus"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC):

## Overview

The systems development life cycle (SDLC) describes the typical phases and progression between phases during the development of a computer-based system; from inception to retirement.(no content)A software development process prescribes a process for developing software and typically divides an overall effort into smaller steps or sub-processes that are intended to ensure high-quality results.

## Key Phases

The SDLC typically includes several important phases:

- **Construction/Implementation**: Based on the design, hardware and software components are created and integrated, including testing sub-components and components.

- **Acceptance/System Testing**: The acceptance phase is about testing the complete system to ensure that it meets customer expectations (requirements).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Autonomous Agents"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous agency theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agency_theory"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Automated negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_negotiation"},{"title":"AutoGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AutoGPT"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Cooperative distributed problem solving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_distributed_problem_solving"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of autonomous agents:

## Definition

An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Key Characteristics

Autonomous agents have capabilities of task selection, prioritization, goal-directed behavior, and decision-making without human intervention, and they are able to engage other components through communication and coordination.(no content)Key notions that distinguish agents from arbitrary programs include reaction to the environment, autonomy, goal-orientation and persistence.

## Modern AI Agents

Agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent) expands the concept of intelligent agents by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.(no content)Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight, and possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.

## Examples

AutoGPT is an open-source autonomous software agent that uses OpenAI's large language models to attempt to achieve a goal specified by a user in natural language, and unlike chatbots that require continuous user commands, AutoGPT works autonomously by breaking the main goal into smaller sub-tasks.

## Applications and Challenges

Autonomous agents increasingly interact with IoT devices, enabling smart home systems, industrial monitoring, and urban infrastructure management. However, autonomous agents must make decisions with limited or uncertain information about their environment, and incorporating autonomous agents into existing systems can be technically challenging and resource-intensive.

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
